titlepage.titleproper: Oral history interviews of the Former Yugoslavia Witnesses Documentation Project, Bosnia

did.unittitle: Oral history interviews of the Former Yugoslavia Witnesses Documentation Project, Bosnia
did.origination: From 2006 to present, the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Oral History Branch has produced interviews in Bosnia for its Former Yugoslavia Witnesses Documentation Project with Mr. Nathan Beyrak as Project Director. The Museum received the first set of interviews for this project in February 2008.

scopecontent.p: Oral history interviews of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum's Former Yugoslavia Witnesses Documentation Project in Bosnia.

did.unittitle: Oral history interview with Dobrila Kukolj
did.origination: Nathan Beyrak, Project Director for the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Oral History Branch, coordinated the interview with Dobrila Kukolj on July 3, 2007, as part of the Museum's Former Yugoslavia Witnesses Documentation Project in Bosnia.

physdesc.extent: 2 videocassettes PAL DVCAM sound, color ; 1/4 in.

acqinfo.p: Credit: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum Collection, Perpetrators, Collaborators, and Witnesses: The Jeff and Toby Herr Testimony Initiative

scopecontent.p: Dobrila Kukolj, born in 1930 in Medjedja (Međeđa) near Bosanska Dubica in the former Yugoslavia (Bosnia and Herzegovina), describes life after the start of World War II and the murders committed by the Ustaše in her town; the capture of her family and their deportation to the Cerovljani camp; her separation from most of her family except her sister; her imprisonment at Jasenovac and the deaths of the children there; her transfer to the village of Toranj, from which she was able to go back to Bosnia after three months; her return home to find her mother alive; and her escape to Kozara until liberation.
